title: 104_hr4016
content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The Secretary reserves funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands, programs for Indian youth, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are also specified. The Secretary allocates funds among states based on school-aged population and previous funding received under part A of title I, with a minimum allotment of one-half of 1 percent of the total amount allotted. The Secretary may reallot funds to a State if it cannot be used within two years. Definitions include 'State' as 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico, and 'local educational agency' as educational service agencies and consortia. SEC. 4112. State applications. To receive funding under section 4111, the State's chief executive officer must submit an application to the Secretary. The application must outline how funds will be coordinated with other programs, provide results of the State's needs assessment for drug and violence prevention, and assure cooperation with the Secretary in conducting a national impact assessment. The State must cooperate with the Secretary in evaluating programs and provide any required information. The Secretary will use a peer review process for reviewing State applications. "State programs under SEC. 4113 require cooperation with the Secretary for program evaluation and information provision. A peer review process is used for reviewing State applications." The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount. Grants are dedicated to financing prevention programs on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. The allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs must be used solely for a strict no-drug-use curriculum. Penalties, including forfeiture and reimbursement, apply to any misapplication of funds. Grants awarded are subject to peer review. The chief executive officer of a State may carry out drug abuse and violence prevention activities directly or through grants. Funds can be used to award grants to law enforcement agencies for programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education. The prevention activities for drug abuse and violence include resisting pressures to experiment with substances, legal education programs, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of national impact on programs combating violence in schools, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. The Secretary will collect data on violence in elementary and secondary schools from states and submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2000, with recommendations and estimated costs. States must submit reports on their program implementation and effectiveness by October 1, 1999, and every third year thereafter. The Secretary will collect data on violence in schools and communities, based on ongoing evaluation activities, including drug use prevalence by youth. The report will be in a specified form, made public, and submitted to Congress by January 1, 2000. States must also submit reports on program implementation and effectiveness by October 1, 1999, and every third year thereafter. The Secretary will provide grants to organizations serving Native Hawaiians for programs authorized by this title. A Native Hawaiian is defined as an individual with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
